20.text: Although the Youanmi 1:250 000 scale map sheet area was not included in the GSWA’s

21.text: sampling  program,  several  significant  uranium  anomalies  were  defined  by  the  GSWA

22.text: sampling undertaken along a major SE-draining channel to the east of the tenement. The

23.text: GSWA sampling was regional in nature and the significant anomalism detected provides

24.text: a strong indication of uranium mineralization being developed within the area.

26.text: The  Radiator  Well  tenement  is  a  greenfields  project  which  covers  an  extensive  linear

27.text: drainage system that has received little to no exploration for uranium.

32.text: uranium mineralization along the northern extension of Lake Noondie.

text:
Although the Youanmi 1:250 000 scale map sheet area was not included in the GSWA’s 
 sampling  program,  several  significant  uranium  anomalies  were  defined  by  the  GSWA 
 sampling undertaken along a major SE-draining channel to the east of the tenement. The 
 GSWA sampling was regional in nature and the significant anomalism detected provides 
 a strong indication of uranium mineralization being developed within the area. 
 The  Radiator  Well  tenement  is  a  greenfields  project  which  covers  an  extensive  linear 
 drainage system that has received little to no exploration for uranium. 
 Along  the  northern  shore  of  Lake  Noondie,  some  70km  west  of  Radiator  Well  lies 
 Aldershot  Resources  Ltd’s.  Yuinmery  uranium  deposit  (1.58Mt  @  0.037%  U3O8: 
 Aldershot).  The  project  area  may  have  some  significant  potential  for  calcrete-hosted 
 uranium mineralization along the northern extension of Lake Noondie.

13.text: in lake sediment samples taken from major drainage systems that had not been subject

14.text: to any or minor prior uranium exploration. Part of the rationale in this selection, was that

15.text: the  prior  phase  of  uranium  exploration  relied  heavily  on  early  generation  and  widely

16.text: spaced airborne radiometrics for initial selection of exploration areas. In addition, any thin

17.text: surficial  cover  present  above  0.5  to  1m  in  thickness  nullifies  any  radiometric  response

17.text: The Radiator Well tenement lies along and astride the northern section of Lake Noondie.

18.text: Lake Noondie is a prominent saline playa lake system which extends for some 100km in

19.text: length  and  up  to  25km  in  width.  The  project  area  is  covered  by  extensive  salt  lake

20.text: sediments and associated alluvial sands, gravels and kopi dunes surrounded by acacia

21.text: and  sheoak  woodland,  Figure  2.  The  geological  environment  within  the  project  area  is

24.text: The Yuinmery deposit is regarded as a playa calcrete type, similar to a number of other

25.text: uranium  deposits  within  the  region  including:  Lake  Austin,  Lake  Raeside,  Lake  Mason

26.text: and Lake Maitland. Within the Yilgarn, this deposit style generally has uranium present as

27.text: the  secondary  mineral  carnotite.  The  uranium  is  derived  from  deep  weathering  of

28.text: surrounding granites; mobilised along Tertiary paleo-drainage systems; and precipitated

29.text: within  the  drainage  channels  or  in  the  vicinity  of  lake  margins  as  a  result  of  complex

32.text: Calcrete-hosted uranium mineralisation along the north-western margin of the lake forms

text:
The Radiator Well tenement lies along and astride the northern section of Lake Noondie. 
 Lake Noondie is a prominent saline playa lake system which extends for some 100km in 
 length  and  up  to  25km  in  width.  The  project  area  is  covered  by  extensive  salt  lake 
 sediments and associated alluvial sands, gravels and kopi dunes surrounded by acacia 
 and  sheoak  woodland,  Figure  2.  The  geological  environment  within  the  project  area  is 
 The Yuinmery deposit is regarded as a playa calcrete type, similar to a number of other 
 uranium  deposits  within  the  region  including:  Lake  Austin,  Lake  Raeside,  Lake  Mason 
 and Lake Maitland. Within the Yilgarn, this deposit style generally has uranium present as 
 the  secondary  mineral  carnotite.  The  uranium  is  derived  from  deep  weathering  of 
 surrounding granites; mobilised along Tertiary paleo-drainage systems; and precipitated 
 within  the  drainage  channels  or  in  the  vicinity  of  lake  margins  as  a  result  of  complex 
 Calcrete-hosted uranium mineralisation along the north-western margin of the lake forms

13.text: Despite  the  interest  in  the  north-western  end  of  Lake  Noondie,  no  previous  uranium

14.text: exploration has been undertaken within the Radiator Well tenement.

16.text: Between  1994  and  2001  GSWA  conducted  a  regional  scale  regolith  geochemical

17.text: sampling program across the adjacent Leonora 1:250 000 map sheet area. The sampling

18.text: was  regional  in  nature  –  with  lake  sample  intervals  of  3  –  6  km  along  a  SE  trending

19.text: channel to the east of the Radiator Well project. Several significant uranium anomalies

20.text: were  defined  within  this  channel,  (Bradley  et.  al.,  1995).  The  significant  anomalism

text:
Despite  the  interest  in  the  north-western  end  of  Lake  Noondie,  no  previous  uranium 
 exploration has been undertaken within the Radiator Well tenement. 
 Between  1994  and  2001  GSWA  conducted  a  regional  scale  regolith  geochemical 
 sampling program across the adjacent Leonora 1:250 000 map sheet area. The sampling 
 was  regional  in  nature  –  with  lake  sample  intervals  of  3  –  6  km  along  a  SE  trending 
 channel to the east of the Radiator Well project. Several significant uranium anomalies 
 were  defined  within  this  channel,  (Bradley  et.  al.,  1995).  The  significant  anomalism

21.text: detected  provides  a strong  indication  of  uranium  mineralization  being  developed  along

22.text: the northern arm of the Lake Raeside drainage system and allows for the possibility of

23.text: uranium mineralisation being developed within the Radiator Well project.

25.text: Between 1994 and 1999 several companies explored the region, including sections of the

26.text: Radiator Well project for diamonds however, no kimberlitic intrusions were identified.

30.text: Liberty’s  exploration  focus  during  the  reporting  period  was  directed  towards  uranium

31.text: mineralisation. Exploration activities included the purchase and interpretation of airborne

32.text: radiometric  data,  the  acquisition  and  evaluation  of  available  reports  and  data  on  the

33.text: project area, the compilation of a GIS database and general field reconnaissance work.

30.text: The airborne radiometrics highlighted an elevated uranium response in the north-eastern

31.text: part of Lake Noondie. The very low uranium response (dark purple) along Lake Noondie

32.text: indicates  that  water  was  present  at  the  time  the  survey  was  flown.  The  water  has

33.text: effectively shielded any surface radiometric response along the Lake. Any other surface

34.text: radiometric  responses  in  the  area  could  be  shielded  by  as  little  as  half  a  metre  of
